online.game
Interface ViewerProtocol

All Superinterfaces:
CanvasProtocol, deferredEventHandler, java.util.Observer, ViewGameProtocol
All Known Implementing Classes:
commonCanvas
public interface ViewerProtocol
extends ViewGameProtocol

Technically speaking, an add-on game for boardspace only needs to implement ViewerProtocol. Everything else is optional.

Generally speaking, the game window will create some class that implements this protocol and call doInit. The game controller will collect the players and spectators and maintain communications with the server and among the players. There are just a few "incoming" type events that the client class will need to handle, and only a few "outgoing" pieces of information that the client will need to provide.

Generally speaking, the client class will generate a series of simple messages that describe the events in the game. All the clients in the game (both spectators and players) work from this stream and maintain their state from it.

Disconnections, reconnections, new spectators, and resumptions of suspended games are handled by requiring the clients to produce a "replay" string, and to be able to parse and interpret similar strings. Generally, these strings are in a format very similar to the routine messages in the game, so essentially new clients are synchronized by feeding them the game history.

Another important point is that error logging is automatic, so information about problems with the client will be available in the debugging environment and on the server.

Author:
ddyer

Method Detail

doInit

void doInit(boolean preserve_history)
initialize back to the "start" position. This is used when a reviewer is about to load a new game, or when the "WayBack" button is pressed. In particular, this implies that the players list (and maybe also the game subtype) may change. As invoked by the game controller, "preserve_history" will always be false, indicating that history should be discarded.

midGamePoint

int midGamePoint()
the number of moves at which midgame is reached, this is just a guess, not a contract. When this point in the game is reached, a midpoint digest is extracted for later use in fraud detection. midGamePoint() only relevant the first time MoveStep() is greater, so a variety of strategies for determining and declaring midpoint could be used.

gameProgressString

java.lang.String gameProgressString()
this is an entertainment string passed to the lobby. The first element is the current move number, the rest are an ordered list of short summary strings, one for each player. There are a couple of undocumented special formats that help the lobby display things prettily

Digest

int Digest()
return an integer representing a hashed digest (Zorbrist hash) of the state of the game. This is used to detect duplicate game fraud, to detect game end by repetition, and to detect internal errors where game state "should" have been preserved

startRobot

void startRobot(commonPlayer p,
                commonPlayer runner)
set up a robot for this player as p.robotPlayer. Don't actually make any moves yet. this is where you instantiate the class that will implement RobotProtocol for the game.

getBoardCoords

java.awt.Point getBoardCoords(int inX,
                              int inY)
get the position of the mouse in board-relative coordinates, independant of the scale of the board. This is used to track the opponent's mouse. The exact coding system is important only to other instances of the same type of viewer, but it must not be a simple 1:1 pixel map, since boards may be different physical sizes. Recommended practice: divide the board into cells based on a square size, and transmit coordinates in units of 1/10 cell. This method may also perform important tasks such as censoring the mouse position when it is acessing hidden parts of the board.

GameOver

boolean GameOver()
return true if the game is over. This triggers recording the score and so on, and also prevents the game from ending more than once

WinForPlayer

boolean WinForPlayer(commonPlayer p)
return true if player p has won. This is used to transmit the winner to the scorekeeper if the game is a draw or inconclusive, all players will return false. It's an error for multiple players to return true

ScoreForPlayer

int ScoreForPlayer(commonPlayer p)
return the final score for this player. This is used in multiplayer games where there may be no "win", but just each player has a score.
